properties.name: Clay Shirky
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishingBrooklyn, NY(from Wikipedia) Clay Shirkyis an American writer, consultant and teacher on the social and economic effects of Internet technologies. He teaches New Media at New York University\'s (NYU) graduate Interactive Telecommunications Program (ITP). His columns and writings appeared in Business 2.0, the New York Times, the Wall Street Journal, the Harvard Business Review and Wired.

properties.name: Georges Harik
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing(from Wikipedia) Georges Harik was Director of Googlettes and a Distinguished Engineer at Google. As Director of Googlettes, his team was responsible for the product management and strategy efforts surrounding many starting Google initiatives including Gmail, Google Talk, Google Video, Picasa, Orkut, Google Groups and Google Mobile. As a Distinguished Engineer, Georges was the co-developer of the technology behind AdSense, the first engineering manager of the Google Search Appliance, and the co-author of the original product plan for the AdWords Online system. Georges has contributed to numerous patents covering Google\'s search engine and advertising networks.

properties.name: Jack Dangermond
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishingLoma Linda, CAJack Dangermond is the co-founder and president of ESRI, a privately-held Geographic Information Systems software company that is headquartered in Redlands, California. In 1969, he co-founded ESRI with his wife, Laura.

properties.name: Paul Dali
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishingNew York, NYPaul Dali is a founder and the Managing General Partner of KeyNote Ventures. His emphasis is on investing in enterprise software, storage and security systems. Past investments and Board seats are: Entegrity Solutions (security software), Repeater Technology (RPTR), Storm Software, MusicVision, @Pos (sold to Symbol), Cybermedia (CYBR acquired by Network Associates), Media Vision and Bizfinity.

properties.name: Ram Shriram
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishingChennai, IndiaRam Shriram served as an officer of Amazon.com working for Jeff Bezos, founder & CEO. Ram came to Amazon.com in August, 1998, when Amazon acquired Junglee, an online comparison shopping firm of which Ram was president. While at Amazon, Ram helped grow the customer base during its early high growth phase in 1998/1999. Before Junglee and Amazon, Ram was a member of the Netscape executive team, joining them in 1994, before they shipped products or posted revenue.

properties.name: Sayumi Abe: Design Intern, Party Animal
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing Sapporo, JapanSayumi was a design intern at Platial for a few months after she got out of school. We met her because an old friend of mine from Iowa who teaches at Wartburg, knew that Sayumi was moving to oregon. When i asked Sayumi how she chose Wartburg College, she told me that she had a huge stack of US college applications and the one to Wartburg, "was on top." She was always funny and friendly and ready to work. We miss her.

properties.name: Tim O'Reilly
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishingCork, IrelandO\'Reilly was initially interested in literature upon graduating from high school, but after graduating from Harvard College in 1975 with a B.A. cum laude in Classics he became involved in the field of computer manuals. Tim defines his company not as a book or online publisher, or as a conference producer (though the company does all three), but as a technology transfer company, "changing the world by spreading the knowledge of innovators." Tim is on the board of CollabNet, and was on the board of Macromedia until its 2005 merger with Adobe. In March 2007, Tim joined MySQL AB’s Board of Directors In 2001, Tim was involved in a dispute with Amazon.com, leading a protest against Amazon\'s one-click patent, and specifically, Amazon\'s use of that patent against rival barnesandnoble.com. The protest ended with Tim and Jeff Bezos visiting Washington D.C. to lobby for patent reform. Amazon has continued to file many patents, and the Barnes & Noble case was settled. As of 2006, Amazon has not repeated the events by suing for patent infringement. In December 2006, O\'Reilly\'s publishing firm donated 0,000 to Creative Commons, demonstrating his interest in the Free Culture movement.
